questions.text: A patient with a history of decreased vision was evaluated with fundus fluorescein angiography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Dye can be seen leaking through abnormal neovascular fronds. Both neovascularization of the disc (NVD), as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE i.e., 2 DD away from the optic disc margin), are seen.

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. The fundoscopic examination picture shows a Hollenhorst plaque as in the image given below.  What is the composition of this plaque?
questions.solution:
A Hollenhorst plaque is composed of cholesterol. The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with the presence of a Hollenhorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Retinal artery occlusion can occur due to emboli from the carotids, atherosclerosis-related thrombosis, retinal arteritis, raised intraocular pressure, etc. Emboli are the most common cause. They may be:

  • Cholestrol emboli or Hollenhorst plaque- at retinal vessel bifurcation, from carotid artery atheromas
  • Calcium emboli from cardiac valves
  • Platelet fibrin emboli from carotid atheromas

Patients present with sudden painless loss of vision and may have a past history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax). On examination, visual acuity is diminished, and the pupillary reflex is lost. On funduscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Narrowed retinal arteries and veins
  • Milky white appearance of the retina due to edema
  • Cherry red spot at the center of the macula
  • Cattle trucking or segmentation of blood column in the retinal veins

CRAO is treated with immediate lowering of intraocular pressure, intermittent ocular massage, iv mannitol, and iv acetazolamide. Vasodilators like nitroglycerine and oral isosorbide dinitrate are helpful. Steroids for arteritis, fibrinolytic therapy, and laser photodiruption of the embolus may be done.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause

  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion

  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball

questions.text: A 65-year-old  female patient presented with progressive painless loss of vision. A fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding?
questions.solution:
The above fundal image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with crenated margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic retinopathy.

Hard exudates are leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages that form due to chronic localized edema. They are commonly seen in the macular area and occur in the outer plexiform layer of the retina. 

Other common causes of hard exudates include hypertensive retinopathy, Coats’ disease, and circinate retinopathy.

Other options:

Option A: Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins that show areas of nerve fiber infarction.

Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

The image below shows a fundus picture with cotton wool spots

 

Option C: Roth spots, shown below, are retinal hemorrhages with white centers that are composed of coagulated fibrin.

They are seen in acute leukemia, bacteremia (subacute bacterial endocarditis), diabetes, hypertension, and anemia.

 

Option D: Cherry red spot, shown below, is seen in central retinal artery occlusion, where the vascular choroid shines through the thin foveal retina, when compared to the surrounding pale retina.

Related Pearl: Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy describes the fundus changes that occur in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded as follows:

  • Grade 1 - Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing
  • Grade 2 - Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).
  • Grade 3 - Grade 2 changes with the following:
    • Copper-wiring of arterioles
    • Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema)
    • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings
    • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings 
      Macular star (Deposition of hard exudates around the fovea) may be present. 
  • Grade 4 - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with worsening night blindness for the last few years. On further questioning, he reveals that he has been having increasing difficulty doing daily activities like reading and walking without bumping into objects. His fundoscopy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a clinical picture of worsening night blindness, difficulty in walking and reading, with fundoscopic features (bone spicule changes, retinal atrophy, and a peripheral ring of depigmentation) is likely to have retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision, which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Ocular examination reveals normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision will be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy shows bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There is severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataracts, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include the following: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency would lead to xerophthalmia. This also has night blindness and loss of vision. However, retinal involvement would be characterized by yellowish, peripheral dots in advanced cases. 

Option C: Retinal detachment occurs when there is a separation between the neuroepithelium and pigment epithelium of the retina. This can occur due to trauma, neoplasm, or fluid accumulation. It is characterized by light flashes, floaters, and a 'curtain' obscuring the vision. Ophthalmoscopy features depend on the stage. Early stages may not be apparent other than color changes, but later stages may show folds that oscillate on eye movement, grey depressions, and bright summits. 

The image given below shows a shifting fluid sign in exudative retinal detachment.

The following image shows central retinal detachment.

Option D: Acquired syphilis is characterized by anterior uveitis, chorioretinitis, and posterior placoid chorioretinopathy. The retina will have a ground-glass appearance and have vasculitis, leading to scars.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient came with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. His cataract surgery was done 3 months back. His optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, and retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, OCT shows foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance".

In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B: Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. 

An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D: Senile macular degeneration also known as age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of blindness in the old age population. Extracellular deposits called drusens are deposited between retinal pigment epithelium and brush membrane.

In OCT drusens can be seen as hyperreflective irregular nodules and severe disruption of the external limiting membrane of the retina from choroid can be seen.

An OCT of age-related macular degeneration showing the separation of 10 layers including retinal pigment epithelium from the choroid is given below:

questions.text: During an ophthalmoscopic examination of a patient in bright light, you notice a finding similar to that of 'A' in the given image. The same patient is made to sit in a dark room and a subsequent examination reveals you a fundus similar to that of 'B'. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows golden yellow colour of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows normal-appearing funds after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours). The fundus has an unusual golden yellow colour in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation is called Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon. 

Mizuo phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease. 

Oguchi's disease is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).

Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterised by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see a 'headlight-in-fog' appearance, as seen below?
questions.solution:
The "headlight-in-fog' appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis. 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infestation due to Toxoplasma gondii. It primarily affects the central nervous system and retina. In humans, it occurs as congenital, acquired, or recurrent.

Toxoplasmosis has a variable presentation. Congenital toxoplasmosis is acquired by the transplacental route. Infants are usually born with inactive disease. Iridocyclitis can be granulomatous or non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, which gives the 'headlight-in-fog' appearance as in the image in question. Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and papillitis with granulomas. 

Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with pigmented borders as in the image below. Bilateral healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular area are usually seen. In acquired toxoplasmosis, punched-out lesions similar to congenital toxoplasmosis are seen. In addition, punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis (PORT) may also be seen. 

 

Other options:

Option A - Posterior staphyloma is used to describe a bulge in the sclera with the choroid behind the equator. On ophthalmoscopy, there is an excavated area with retinal vessels dipping in it. 

Option B - Fundal coloboma occurs due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft. It appears as a comet-shaped defect with the apex towards the disc which may or may not be involved. A few choroidal or retinal vessels may also be seen on the surface. 

Option C - Congenital rubella typically produces a salt and pepper appearance of the fundus.

questions.text: On routine examination of a neonate, the left eye was smaller in size and had a white pupillary reflex. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is persistent fetal vasculature.

The points in the clinical vingette pointing to this diagnosis are: 

  • White pupillary reflex in the left eye (unilateral leukocoria)
  • Smaller size of the left eye (microphthalmos) and 
  • Fundoscopy image showing a leash of vascularized fibrous tissue extending from the back of the lens to the optic nerve head

Persistent fetal vasculature was earlier known as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. It is the failure of primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress. This eventually leads to contraction and opacification combined with the hypoplasia of the posterior portion of the vascular meshwork.

It is unilateral in most of the cases. It is bilateral in cases that are associated with Trisomy 13, trisomy 22, Norries disease, and Walkers Warburg syndrome. 

Clinical Findings include:

  1. Leukocoria
  2. Microphthalmia 
  3. Shallow anterior chamber 
  4. Retrolental cataract 
  5. Esotropia 
  6. Angle-closure glaucoma 
  7. Dilated iris vessels 
  8. Persistent hyaloid artery 
  9. Vitreous hemorrhage
  10. Tractional retinal detachment 

Investigations:

  • CT scan of orbit to evaluate for the presence of calcification, which is present in retinoblastoma but absent in persistent fetal vasculature. 
  • B-scan ultrasonography to evaluate for retinal detachment when a cataract limits the view to the retina.

Treatment is done by pars plana lensectomy and vitrectomy to remove the retrolental fibrovascular membrane to prevent angle-closure glaucoma, followed by aggressive amblyopia therapy

Image below shows the falciform fold of detached dysplastic retina encircling the persistent hyaloid artery that extends from the optic nerve head to the retrolental mass.

Option A:

Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Retinoblastoma arises from the neurosensory retina. Leukocoria and squint are the most common presentation of retinoblastoma. It may also present as painful red eye, cataract, buphthalmos, proptosis(not microphthalmos) and pseudohypopyon.

Option B:

Coats' disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia that is generally of onset in early childhood. It presents as unilateral visual loss, leukocoria (because of exudative retinal detachment), and strabismus. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation. 

The image below shows total retinal detachment with subretinal exudate containing cholesterol crystals and a fibrous nodule in the posterior pole seen in Coats' disease.

Option C:

Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the inner layers of the retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.

Fundus shows smooth and convex (usually round) retinal detachment. Shifting fluid will be seen in exudative type. Shaffer's sign - Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the fundal image showing laminar dot sign is suggestive of Glaucoma.

Laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc. It is because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible as grey dots due to thinning of neuroretinal rim in these patients.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign: Sharp angulation of vessel at margin of excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

Note: As the damage progresses, all the neural tissue of the disc is destroyed and the optic nerve head appears white and deeply excavated resulting in Glaucomatous optic atrophy.

In Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), the fundus shows yellowish-white spots in the macular region called drusens (shown in the image below) 

Related Pearl: Classification of optic atrophy

  • Simple optic atrophy: (Primary) Image below
    • Pathology lies in portion of optic nerve behind lamina cribrosa.
    • Causes are multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis, and traumatic optic neuropathy.
    • Well defined disc margin and chalky white in color.

Post-neuritic optic atrophy: (Secondary)

  • Occurs after disc edema.
  • Causes are Papillitis and papilledema
  • Blurred disc margin and dirty white in color
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive pathology of retina.
    • Causes are retinitis pigmentosa and any cause of diffuse chorioretinitis
    • Well defined disc margin and pale waxy disc.
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy/Cavernous optic atrophy:
    • 100% cupping
    • Bayonetting of vessels
    • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA.

Central serous retinopathy refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Other options:

Option B- Petaloid appearance is seen in cystoid macular edema

Option C- Stars in the sky appearance is suggestive of drusen

Option D- Dual circulation is a pathognomonic feature of choroidal melanoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, the anterior segment was normal, fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings given in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical viginette of female patient on treatment for chronic arthritis which is most likely the drug chloroquine given for rheumatoid arthritis, now presenting with decreased visual acuity, fundoscopy with a typical bull's eye sign and Fundus fluroscein angiography showing increased fluroscence in the macular area is suggestive of chloroquine toxicity.

Chloroquine and it's derivative hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) are antimalarial drugs which is also used to treat connective tissue disorders such as Rheumatoid arthritis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and Discoid Lupus.

The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours while for hydroxychloroquine it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity and hence is percived to be a safer drug but with weaker anti-inflammatory effect.

Manifestations of Chloroquine toxicity:

  • Reversible on stopping the drug: difficulty in night vision, blurring of vision, diplopia, keratopathy
  • Central and paracentral scotomas
  • Earliest fundus findings: blunting of foveal reflex, irregularity in the macular pigmentation.
  • Advanced stages: 'Bull's eye maculopathy' where the central irregular pigmentation may become surrounded by a concentric zone of hypopigmentation
  • End-stage appearance includes bullseye maculopathy, pigmentary degeneration of retina and bone spicule formation, vascular attenuation, and optic atropy.

Screening should include a baseline examination for all patients before starting these drugs followed by annual screening starting after 5 years of use.

Pre-existing maculopathy is considered a contraindication to treatment with chloroquine and HCQ because underlying abnormalities may mask early toxicity.

Screening examinations include visual acuity testing, dilated fundus examination, spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) testing, and functional assessment with Humphrey test.

Various causes of Bull's eye maculopathy are:

  1. Chloroquine and HCQ toxicity
  2. Cone-Rod dystrophy
  3. Advanced stargardt's disease
  4. Clofazimine retinopathy

questions.text: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPD with visual complaints. What does it suggest?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema:

  • Early-stage:
    • Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first)
    • Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc
    • Mild hyperemia of the disc
    • The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer
  • Established papilledema:
    • The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped)
    • Macular fan appears
    • Paton’s lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nerve fibers
    • Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spot
    • Veins become tortuous and engorged
    • Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages
  • Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema:
    • The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork
    • Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface
  • Atrophic stage:
    • Secondary optic atrophy

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy

questions.text: A 69-year-old man who is a chronic smoker, hypertensive, and has a BMI of 35 kg/m2 complains of diminished vision in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36 BE and the anterior segment appears normal. His fundus is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image which shows drusen (druplets) are a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). 

Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of ARMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

There are two types of ARMD:

  • Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) ARMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry ARMD. Antioxidants like the AREDS2 supplements have proven effective.
  • Wet (exudative, neovascular) ARMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

Clinical classification:

Category

Definition

(based on the presence of lesions within two disc diameters of the fovea in either eye)
No apparent
age-related changes		 No drusen
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Normal age-related
changes		 Only drusen
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Early ARMD Medium Drusen (>63 μm but <125 μm)
No AMD pigmentary abnormalities
Intermediate ARMD Large Drusen (>125 μm)
Any ARMD pigmentary
abnormalities
Late ARMD Neovascular ARMD and/or
any geographic atrophy

questions.text: Which stage of ROP  is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Image shows intraretinal ridge formation and it corresponds to stage 2 of ROP.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), previously known as retrolental fibroplasia, is a disease of the eye that affects prematurely born babies.
  • ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. As such, all premature babies are at risk for ROP, and very low birth weight is an additional risk factor.
  • Both oxygen toxicity and relative hypoxia can contribute to the development of ROP.
  • Location
    Concentric zones centered on the optic disc are described.
    • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the center of the macula. 
    • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the center of the disc to the nasal ora serrata.
    • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II
  • Stages of ROP:
    • Stage 1: Demarcation line
    • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
    • Stage 3: Neovascularization
    • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
    • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment
  • "Plus" disease signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. 
  • Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon but if untreated usually progresses to stage 5, sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.
  • Screening
    • First ROP screening should be done at 4 weeks if the gestational age is 28–34 weeks or birth weight is <2000 g.
    • First ROP screening should be done at 3 weeks if gestational age is <28 weeks or birth weight is <1200 g.
  • Treatment
    • Type 1. Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours for type 1 disease. It is done by laser photocoagulation of peripheral avascular retina.
    • Type 2 disease requires observation for progression.
    • Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents, e.g., bevacizumab (only for AP-ROP)
    • Laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina
    • Pars plana vitrectomy for tractional retinal detachment not involving the macula (stage 4A)

  • Type 1 ROP
    1) Zone I ROP with plus disease
    2) Zone I, no plus, stage 3 ROP
    3) Zone II with plus, stage 2 or 3 ROP

Note: Non-type 1 ROP is labelled type 2 ROP

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a sudden, severe diminution of vision in his right eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect is present. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient with the fundoscopic findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

The clinical vignette of a patient developing sudden, severe painless diminution of vision, with relative afferent pupillary defect and funduscopy of the eye showing massive retinal haemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance, are all suggestive of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

Other features of ischaemic CRVO on fundoscopy include numerous cotton wool spots - usually more than 6 to 10, disc showing oedema and hyperaemia, and the macular area is full of haemorrhages and is severely oedematous.

In later stages, the fundus shows marked sheathing around veins, with collaterals and neovascularization seen around and at the disc or periphery respectively.
Macula shows marked pigmentary changes and chronic cystoid oedema.

The complications include Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occurs within 3 months and this is also called "90 days glaucoma".

Vitreous haemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy may also occur in a few cases. Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

Other options:
Option A: Non-ischaemic CRVO, also called venous stasis retinopathy, is characterised by sudden onset mild to moderate blurring of vision. Relative afferent pupillary defect is either absent or if present, mild. Pathognomonic features of ischaemic CRVO differentiating it from non-ischaemic CRVO are the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), visual field defects and reduced amplitude of b-wave on electroretinogram

Option C: Branched retinal vein occlusion is characterised by a sudden painless onset of blurred vision if the macula is involved, whereas peripheral occlusion is asymptomatic. Iris neovascularization and neovascular glaucoma are both less common in BRVO than in CRVO. On fundoscopy, dilatation and tortuosity of the affected venous segment is observed, with flame-shaped and dot/blot haemorrhages in the retinal area. Cotton wool spots and retinal edema may also be present.

Option D: Central retinal artery occlusion is characterised by sudden profound loss of vision, that is painless and visual acuity is severely reduced. Relative afferent pupillary defect is profound, giving rise to an amaurotic pupil and fundoscopy shows the presence of a cherry red spot at the region of the foveola. The peripapillary retina appears swollen and opaque.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is on ART for AIDS presented with difficulty in vision. Fundoscopic examination revealed the following finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following subfamilies of the Herpesviridae family encompasses the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy in an immunocompromised person is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. It belongs to beta viruses subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses (e.g. HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus)
  • Beta herpes viruses (e.g. CMV)
  • Gamma herpesviruses (e.g. EBV)

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. On physical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted on ocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the best immediate step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The best immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options.

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis, varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following: 

  • Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similar episode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex is absent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination shows marked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattle track appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor.

A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. Fundus examination revealed the findings as shown in the image below. The abdominal examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a fundus image showing a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease. 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides. GM2 ganglioside accumulates more commonly in neurons of the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina.

Tay-Sachs disease is common among people from the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Affected infants usually present with loss of motor skills, exaggerated startle response to noise (hyperacusis), seizures, and macrocephaly without hydrocephalus.

On examination of the fundus, a cherry-red spot appears in the macula in almost all patients. This is produced by the accentuation of the red color of the macular choroid, against the background of the rest of the retina appearing pale due to ganglion cells being swollen with GM2 ganglioside.

Histopathological examination reveals ballooned-out neuronal tissue with vacuoles representing lysosomes filled with gangliosides.

Note that cherry red spots are associated with multiple conditions, as discussed in the pearl below and should always be interpreted in the context of the clinical history.
